API uh management and abstraction layer for uh your apis and microservices it
allows you to securely and uh easily configure apis and microservices at
scale uh without having to deal with massive deployments and re architecting systems or even changing the way you
design your apis um it really works on the HTP layer alone and it's very unopinionated about how apis are done or
built uh which is part of the appeal to a lot of people because in today's world of API technology people come in from
soap people come in from rest people come in from different kind of mindset to what's the best architecture and
format to you know deliver apis and uh in a lot of ways a lot of the tools and
services out there are very opinionated uh for various reasons um so what we did with Kong we wanted to keep it
unopinionated we wanted to keep it abstract and more associated with the HTTP layer which is the spec that the
entire web runs on um so that's what really Kong gives you is the ability to control manage and configure your apis
in a way that is completely agnostic to how your backend or actual apis operate
so just notice that you use apis plural there so this is for somebody who has a
handful maybe half a dozen maybe more different apis that they're offering
either publicly or internally so so not necessarily and this is Again part of the um the kind of uh the chaos that the
industry is in today yeah it's not necessarily a negative state of chaos is just a kind of entropy state where
things are just evolving and happening around us um so Mass shape actually started out as uh with our first product
was the API Marketplace um and kind of the short pitch for that it's eBay for apis so API providers and Publishers can
come in and publish their API through the marketplace whether it's free or monetized Iz uh and then just expose it
to a vast majority and a vast community of users and then the consumers of the API or people who are building
applications can come and discover and select apis that fit their needs for building their applications as part of
being the marketplace uh our tools and our uh proxies and our um Marketplace
itself had to literally support Every Which Way that API providers build apis
and had to support Every Which Way that API consumers expect to consume apis so we can't be opinion we couldn't be uh

modularization componentization and microservices um so these three things
are completely independent and you know overlapping in a lot of ways typically
in my view uh modularization is more about the code you modularize your code
so all the benefits that people talk about about microservices is just a way that you can package things together
there's you know single focus and testable and blah blah blah yeah but that's more about being modular right so
you can you can do that as part of codes and libraries and the way you organize your project same thing for components
um components are just a bunch of modules put together to serve a purpose so you can talk about a module being uh
a login module uh or you can talk about a module being a uh username lookup
module and another module being the password verification module and then together they become the login
component and then in terms of services or microservices as the term is today same thing with s SOA it's more about
how these components which exist of composed of multiple modu modules are

it's entirely focused on the HTTP layer as opposed to S SOA doesn't really
prescrib to being over HTP or not it just happens to be in a lot of cases but microservices focus on no no no let's
just do things as the web has evolved over HTTP let's do things as well over HTTP between our products and tools and
services within it um so I think you know generally speaking um and again because we had to be the marketplace for
so long we were're fine with all of that um U you know obviously people have personal opinions but the end of the day
if if you're building a product that's uh serving a solving a a problem for for
your users they don't really care about are you restful or are you soap or are
you microservices Ora or so on uh the point is a product and that's kind of our message that we carry to people when
we talking about an API API is a product it's not just a data output it's not just a
extension of a product it is a product of itself because the users of that product are the developers who are
supposed to be interacting with it so just as we have product teams and marketing teams and um kind of big
initiatives around uh product marketing we should have the same thing for apis because we do see them as products so
when you have a company that builds um uh apis for extending their offerings to

look at apis as these individual products uh however you want to look at it whether it's a multitude of
microservices or a big monolithic AP or SOA or so on it doesn't really matter
yeah I think we run into just name name spacing issues when it comes to terms like modules and components and and we
we move uh fluidly up and down the stack in our conversations with each other
that often times Things become conflated because perhaps you're talking about modules at a network layer or I'm
talking about them at an application layer or even inside of a code you know a library or something so yeah it it
becomes we can mince words and I think it's it's still important to talk about these things and and try to come to like

realize that all these apis which we view as products individual products they all share these common attributes
these common needs and so why are we all implementing all off and logging and

apis and provides that is that does that paint the right picture yeah that's precisely it and Kong actually evolved
in the marketplace itself because you know as virtue of being able to offer monetization services for API providers
through the market place that means we had to manage their their API calls as well meaning proxying so everything has
to go through our system so that we can track it and appropriately charge for the APA calls and so on and then um
process it for the consumer so we actually built conch for our for ourselves and because like I said our
need for the marketplace was to be everything for everybody and actually you not be opinionated at all that went
into the DNA of making Kong so the idea that we have uh the authentication and
rate limiting and caching control and all these kind of things built into the core really started out because of of
the marketplace need but then what happened is as the product of the marketplace grew and our clientele kind
of became more Diversified we had more Enterprise clients who wanted to have things running with their own infrastructure uh we had uh people who
were worried more about the latency and they were perhaps using regions on AWS they're not as close to our regions so
then we had to worry about how do we actually become a global distribution of a proxy service across multiple regions
without adding any delay or without losing any context of the data and all these things played in to the kind of
the the makeup and the DNA of Kong so like you said it's this idea that when
you're focusing on building a e-commerce product or you're focusing on building even a mobile uh uh application or an

you're still responsible for the maintenance of them so think in a scenario where there's a company that has uh oh don't go too far talk about

whether it's you know PlayStations or uh mobile phones or desktop uh TV smart TVs

um you know control over what the API is doing and perhaps as they evolve and as they grow as a company they want to change these apis
add new versions add new functionality all of a sudden you're faced with this massive interconnected web of
dependencies and uh rep repeatable things that you're doing over and over over again um obviously like you said
the examples that ring true for a lot of people is authentication is one of the simplest one yeah um you have multiple
systems multiple apis they each have an authentication it's the same authentication mechanism you're doing
oath on both or perhaps you're doing G tokens or something similar but it's the same thing why does it have to live in
two different places and then as as part of having to be on the application layer itself it has to also scale with it so
you know scaling problems become also an issue and how do you maintain the session and the information across servers and all that stuff so with Kong
the idea is that you you abstract all of these things away and you move them to the proxy layer and the reality is a lot
of people are already running engine X as their HTTP server or their proxy server and that's also why we chose
engin X as the core uh for Kong So Kong actually runs on top of engine x what it
gives you is the ability to configure enginex servers and configure the proxying mechanisms of engine X
dynamically through a restful API of itself um so in the olden days you can
actually just set up engine X and configure it to do everything you want including custom customization of things
like authentication uh Beyond just the basic authentication you can use Lua as the scripting language with open resty
on it engine X to customize it um but you would have to do it in configuration files and you have to deploy these

um and sure there are tooling that help you with that things like chef and anible cloud formation on
AWS but that's now becoming a big massive uh undertaking for a small team
or even a bigger team in an Enterprise company now they have to deal with different departments doing different things perhaps between development and
Dev Ops and it and so on so with Kong you literally have one thing to deal
with which is the API you actually make a call to the Kong admin API in itself
and tell Kong to create a new endpoint you tell Kong to add authentication you tell Kong to add logging and so on and
